TaskText:
A) Run the simulation with A population size, _S~0~_, of 1000, 1 initially infected presymptomatic host, _P~0~_, simulation duration _tmax_= 200 days. Assume that only symptomatic individuals transmit, at rate _b~I~_ = 0.001. Assume that the duration of the presymptomatic, asymptomatic and symptomatic periods are all 5 days long. (Hint: The parameters _g~P~_, _g~A~_, and _g~I~_ are the inverses of these periods.) Assume that there are no asymptomatic infections, _f_=0, and nobody dies due to disease _d_=0. If you did it correctly, your outbreak should end with around 7 susceptibles remaining.
B) Check the results with the assumptions for the model and make sure they agree. For instance you shouldn't get any deaths, and no asymptomatic infected. From the graph, contemplate how you would estimate the day at which the outbreak peaks. What's the problem? How would you solve it? Rerun the simulation, with the same values you just had. Does anything change? Why (not)?
Record: Total number of recovered at end of outbreak

TaskText:
A) Assume now that half of the infected are asymptomatic. Don't change any other assumption. What do you expect to get for the number/fraction of S/I/R at the end of the outbreak and the time at which the outbreak peaks?
B) Run another simulation, record the same values as above. Compare your expectations with the results. How do they agree/disagree? Does it make sense? Anything surprising happening?

A) Assume now that half of the infected are asymptomatic. Don't change any other assumption. What do you expect to get for the number/fraction of S/I/R at the end of the outbreak and the time at which the outbreak peaks?
B) Run another simulation, record the same values as above. Compare your expectations with the results. How do they agree/disagree? Does it make sense? Anything surprising happening?
Record: Total number infected at end of outbreak

TaskText: A) Now assume that the asymptomatics transmit at the same rate as the symptomatic. Change _b~A~_ accordingly. Leave everything else as before. How do you expect the results to change? (Try to make as precise/quantitative a prediction as you can). Run another simulation, compare your expectations with the results. How do they agree/disagree? Does it make sense? Anything surprising happening?

A) Now assume that the asymptomatics transmit at the same rate as the symptomatic. Change _b~A~_ accordingly. Leave everything else as before. How do you expect the results to change? (Try to make as precise/quantitative a prediction as you can). Run another simulation, compare your expectations with the results. How do they agree/disagree? Does it make sense? Anything surprising happening?
Record: Total number recovered at end of outbreak

TaskText:
A) Next, let's assume that half the symptomatic infected die. Change the corresponding parameter in the model to reflect this new assumption. Leave everything as in task 3.How do you expect the results to change?
B) Run another simulation, record the same values as above. Compare your expectations with the results. How do they agree/disagree? Does it make sense? Anything surprising happening?

A) Next, let's assume that half the symptomatic infected die. Change the corresponding parameter in the model to reflect this new assumption. Leave everything as in task 3.How do you expect the results to change?
B) Run another simulation, record the same values as above. Compare your expectations with the results. How do they agree/disagree? Does it make sense? Anything surprising happening?

A) Set all transmission parameters to 0.0005, leave everything else as before. What do you expect will happen to the peak of _P_ and _I_ as well as the total fraction of population ever infected (i.e., _R_ + _D_ at the end of simulation), compared to the previous task? (use these values for the recorded max values below)
B) Further explore how changes in the infectiousness of the different groups (_b~P~_, _b~A~_, _b~I~_) and the average time a person spends in each of those states (_g~P~_, _g~A~_, _g~I~_) affects the infection dynamics. Every time, think about what you expect to get, then run the simulation, compare your expectations with the results. Then make sense of it.

A) Using the settings from task 5 part A, now assume that 90% of infections are asymptomatic. How do things change?
B) Further explore how changes in the fraction becoming asymptomatic and fraction dying does (or does not) affect the infection dynamics. Every time, think about what you expect to get, then run the simulation, compare your expectations with the results. Then make sense of it.
